def get_tfidf_keywords(documents, document, topn=10, ngram=(1, 2)):
    cvec = CountVectorizer(ngram_range=ngram, max_df=0.75, min_df=1, stop_words='english') 
    cvec_term_doc = cvec.fit_transform(documents)
    tvec = TfidfTransformer(smooth_idf=True, norm = None, use_idf=True)
    feature_names = cvec.get_feature_names()
    tvec.fit(cvec_term_doc)
    tfidf = tvec.transform(cvec.transform(document), copy=False)
    sorted_items = sort_coo(tfidf.tocoo())
    keywords = extract_topn_from_vector(feature_names, sorted_items, topn)
    return keywords

# Sort sparse matrix 
def sort_coo(coo_matrix):
    tuples = zip(coo_matrix.col, coo_matrix.data)
    return sorted(tuples, key=lambda x: (x[1], x[0]), reverse=True)

def extract_topn_from_vector(feature_names, sorted_items, topn):
    sorted_items = sorted_items[:topn]
    score_vals = []
    feature_vals = []
    for idx, score in sorted_items:
        score_vals.append(round(score, 3))
        feature_vals.append(feature_names[idx])
    results= {}
    for idx in range(len(feature_vals)):
        results[feature_vals[idx]]=score_vals[idx]
    return results

source.04f56c64:
In Jigsaw's new Toxicity Classification our goal is minimizing uninteded bias- this EDA is a review of work published by Jigsaw and an exploration of features that influence bias.

Content: - [Word Embeddings](#embeddings) - [Data Imbalance](#imbalance) - [Vocabulary Coverage](#coverage) - [Data Augmentation](#augmentation) I think the best starting point for this competition is reading about **Unintended Bias** and what **Jigsaw** has done so far- [this is the best article](https://medium.com/the-false-positive/unintended-bias-and-names-of-frequently-targeted-groups-8e0b81f80a23) I've found, hidden on medium and written by the Jigsaw team. Here's the gist: The original Jigsaw model would get false-positives because of the use of identity terms in slurs and abusive language. This led to positive comments with those same identities earning inappropriately high toxicity scores. Before the model launch the team thought that bias came from: - Word embeddings - Error from human data annotators This motivated more work with with frequently targeted groups to collect data and produce particular tests- but > None of these tests highlighted the unintended biases that we found after opening the API for public testing using the demo Thus, the reason for this competition. Highlights of Jigsaw work since: 1. People's entries on their demo page has been the largest source of debiasing data, particularly for **short entries mentioning identity terms** 2. Balancing data, discussed more in-depth [here](https://github.com/conversationai/unintended-ml-bias-analysis/blob/master/presentations/measuring-mitigating-unintended-bias-paper.pdf) 3. Pinned AUC, which you can explore in [their colab](https://colab.research.google.com/github/conversationai/unintended-ml-bias-analysis/blob/master/unintended_ml_bias/pinned_auc_demo.ipynb) 4. Building open datasets and partnerships for new datasets
source.81da7e85: Since debiasing seems to be a data problem, lets begin with an overview of the Toxicity Classification data.
source.ad68c067: First, I checked for overlapping comments between the old and new Jigsaw competition, and because it didn't seem like much I decided to keep all of it.
source.d4f613dd: ### Data Augmentation --- Data augmentation is Jigsaw's primary strategy to de-bias their model. In [their paper](http://www.aies-conference.com/wp-content/papers/main/AIES_2018_paper_9.pdf) that I've linked a couple times they focus on using samples from Wikipedia Talk Pages to balance out toxic examples with identity terms. Their approach is to balance the ratio of toxic to non-toxic examples in subgroups to match the ratio for the population, with extra consideration to matching comment length (they are using a convolutional model). They also create a synthetic dataset using 'phrase templates'- which makes me think that a context-free-grammar could be a simple yet effective approach. For my data augmentation examples, I want to mine the old toxic classification competition for data, and try to create synthetic data with [Markov Chains](https://www.kaggle.com/jpmiller/extending-train-data-with-markov-chains-auc).
source.4ddc961a: Unfortunately, this doesn't seem to work- the classifier returns about random chance of classifying a comment as belonging to the subgroup 'black'. source.d6a4f051: ### Data Imbalance --- The biggest driver of bias in toxic classification is imbalance in data, below we have two charts that show: - toxic vs non-toxic comments for each identity - toxic vs non-toxic for each identity and total comments
source.4d3cb80b: Next, let's start thinking about the vocabulary and how we will represent each subgroup's comments. We know for neural networks we will likely be using pre-trained word embeddings to represent each word in each comment. How long we make these sequences is an important parameter, and in pytorch we can explore dynamic sequence lenghts for our encoded comments.
source.40e21599: ### Word Embeddings --- I wanted to address word embeddings first, because it was mentioned by Jigsaw and becuase of this [rockstar kernel where I benchmarked embeddings in terms of bias](https://www.kaggle.com/nholloway/combining-embeddings-and-benchmarking-bias). Even though bias seems to stem from data there was a well-known paper in the past about gender biased word embeddings and how to de-bias word embeddings, which I think influenced the team. There has since been work to correct embeddings but even in the above linked kernel we can see variation in performance among word embeddings, and idenitites that consistently score low: black, white, and homosexual_gay_or_lesbian.
source.bf4c17e0: In this long operation we will see how much of each subgroup's vocabulary and text can be represented by pre-trained GloVe embeddings, how large each group's vocabulary is, and the size of their unique vocabulary.
source.6ab7c61b: Exploring our vocabularies can be really important. Ideally we can represent all of the words and therefore all of the information for all comments- but particularly for comments with key identities. My goal is to find opportunities to increase model accuracy by finding important words that aren't covered by our word vectors. [Here](https://www.kaggle.com/adityaecdrid/public-version-text-cleaning-vocab-65) is a great kernel about text cleaning for greater coverage.
